ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Vocabulary and grammar structures to be able to communicate more fluently on modern topics.

This course really helped with high-level language skills. I feel confident that I can hold an intellectual conversation about climate change, protests, or the urban/rural divide with a native speaker. The course was both extremely beneficial for my language skills and my knowledge of contemporary Russia.

My instructor was Liana Battsaligova:

Expanding Russian vocabulary, the ability to talk about a wider variety of subjects, interesting topics in Russian history and culture, reviewing grammatical concepts like participles, expressing purpose, ect.
I learned Russian on a high level. I became better at reading in particular.
I developed a greater understanding of the modern Russian language. This course also helped me improve my Russian writing skills dramatically.

We learned more about gerunds, participles, passive and active voice, and other grammatical topics. My vocabulary increased significantly as homework often involved watching movies, reading articles and listening to interviews in preparation for class.

I got a lot of practice reading and speaking Russian, especially in real-world contexts. We focused on political topics such as global warming, protests, and monument controversies, which I feel gave me a great vocabulary base for political conversations. We worked on tricky grammar rules and consistently used them in speaking practice.

I learned Russian vocabulary related to the environment, politics, and current events. I also had the chance to practice my speaking, reading, and listening skills and learn about advanced grammar concepts such as word order and passive voice.
I learned more advanced Russian and did readings in Russian.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this is a great course. I really enjoyed the topics we discussed and the way Irina Andreevna brings in a lot of diverse, current materials to discuss-- I felt really plugged into current Russian discourses. I thought it's a good mix of troubleshooting grammar and pushing our vocabulary forward. I also am really happy to say that the amount of work felt "just right" this semester -- still a good chunk, but much more manageable than last semester.

The course did an amazing job keeping every motivated and engaged in this era of online learning! I was so impressed with how Liana motivated us all through her own passion and patience. The only weakness to this class was the amount of homework. I definitely felt a bit worn out by the end of the semester, but that was likely more due to COVID and Zoom than the amount of homework.

I was in Liana Battsaligova's section:

This is a fantastic course, there are lots of opportunities to speak, the topics are diverse and interesting, and the syllabus was very flexible according to student needs.  The choice of films was also very interesting and I enjoyed the discussions following them and the opportunity to write an analytical essay in Russian.  We also had very clear and in depth materials for review and received in depth feedback for every homework assignment.  The workload was also well distributed and I never felt like I was overwhelmed with tasks to complete or the need to do a ton of studying for tests as having done the homework assignments helped with the preparation.
It's difficult to find weaknesses in the course.
The course is very strong as it is. Perhaps the one thing I would have liked to see more of would be more literature. Otherwise, every single assignment was very engaging and helpful.

The biggest strength is Irina! She is compassionate and extremely responsive to student needs. She tailors the course according to what we needed to work on based off the assignments and exams. A weakness is perhaps that it is difficult to practice in class since we are virtual but that is largely unavoidable. That being said Irina went to great lengths to make sure we all spoke during class with break out rooms, in class discussion and so on

The format of the course is great and Irina takes student interests into consideration. She is very focused on speaking practice which I feel is a strength to any language class. We learn a lot of vocabulary and often return to previous units' vocab lists. The grammar practice was always useful and Irina was always willing to answer questions and clarify. I don't think this course had any weaknesses that couldn't be attributed to the difficulties of distance learning.

Strengths: Irina Andreevna is a wonderful teacher, and our classes were always engaging. I appreciated that we had the chance to study a wide range of topics and mediums, including authentic news articles, videos, films, and songs. Weaknesses: Sometimes the homework assignments were on the long side. But overall the workload is manageable and the material is very interesting.
It is a reading focused class and reading skills improve a lot. I would have liked more listening material on top of the readings.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course did an amazing job of providing intimate and fun spaces to practice our language skills. The small class sizes allowed for a lot of participation and a lot of practice opportunities. In many ways, the class felt like a normal in-person class.

I was in Liana Battsaligova's section:

This course was well adapted to the online course formal.  I thought zoom discussions were engaging even if they weren't in person.
I think all the practices succeeded. The discussions were very dynamic, despite the virtual environment.

Irina spent a lot of time in class speaking with us since we did not have a lot of other avenues for speaking practice. She lightened the homework load but still managed to fit in the topics we planned to discuss. Her use of screen sharing and videos was always helpful and engaging. We often used breakout rooms and engaged in discussions or debates to work through topics and use new vocabulary and grammar that we had learned.
The course went well over Zoom.
It was virtual and was done live. Can't think of ways to improve

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I think the Russian professors at Yale are really great.
100%! An amazing opportunity to keep practicing your Russian and to learn about contemporary Russia.

I was in Liana Battsaligova's section:

I would absolutely recommend this course.  I enjoyed the emphasis on different topics that incorporated grammatical concepts into them rather than just focusing solely on grammar in isolation.  I felt like I improved both my written and spoken Russian.  I would recommend this course to students that are looking to engage with a variety of Russian language materials, especially news articles.  Although the course is pretty rigorous and contains a lot of material and vocabulary, the overall atmosphere was not very stressful at all.
Yes, if you want to take Russian
I would absolutely recommend this course to any student who is looking to improve their Russian language comprehension skills.

Yes there is no world in which you have gotten this far in the Russian sequence and it is in your best interest not to take this course. Its a must take for anyone who is able. Your Russian will improve significantly and the class is simply a joy! I also feel extremely prepared to take courses conducted entirely in Russian that are not about the language so please take this course!!!
Yes! If you want to improve your Russian and engage with some interesting and relevant topics regarding Russia and the world, this is a great class to take!
Yes! This is a great class, especially if you are interested in honing your reading/writing skills and understanding the nuances of Russian grammar.
I will only recommend the class to people seriously pursuing Russian.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also watched movies and read a lot of articles outside of class time.
We met three times a week by Zoom in a synchronous lesson.
